results.statement: Understanding Recurrent Ascites. Symptoms may include abdominal distension, discomfort, and shortness of breath. 1,2
results.matched_evidence:
- 2. Madhumita Premkumar,2025.pdf: Recurrent ascites refers to fluid accumulation in the abdomen that returns at least three times per year, despite dietary sodium restriction and diuretic treatment.
- 1.Chiejina M,2023.pdf: Patients typically report progressive abdominal distension that may be painless or associated with abdominal discomfort, weight gain, early satiety, shortness of breath, and dyspnea resulting from fluid accumulation and increased abdominal pressure.
results.page_location: Page 1, paragraph 1 | Page 2, section 'History and Physical'

results.statement: What Are Your Treatment Options?. Compare your options for managing recurrent ascites.³
results.matched_evidence: - 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: Fig. 3. Treatment options for malignant ascites (MA): divided in green: causative treatment options targeting the underlying malignancy via systemic or intraperitoneal cytotoxic therapy, cytoreductive surgery or targeted therapy; orange: symptomatic treatment options with paracentesis, permanent drainages, peritoneo-venous shunts or diuretics; blue: experimental approaches reinvigorating the immunosuppressive environment within ascites using humoral or cellular approaches. *.

results.statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Large volume paracentesis (LVP) involves insertion of a needle into the peritoneal cavity to drain excess fluid and provide temporary relief from recurrent ascites.3,4
results.matched_evidence:
- 4.Aponte EM, 2019.pdf: Therapeutic paracentesis relieves the abdominal pain, distension, and respiratory compromise associated with large-volume ascites, significantly improving patient comfort and function.|Therapeutic paracentesis is indicated in hemodynamically stable individuals with tense ascites, particularly when ascites is refractory to diuretics or causing significant abdominal discomfort and respiratory compromise.[2][8] Large-volume paracentesis (LVP), defined as removing more than 5 liters of fluid, is frequently required in these patients.[2]
- 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: Ascites formation is a common complication of cancer with a significant symptomatic burden for patients.|Malignant ascites (MA) is defined by the presence of tumor cells within the ascitic fluid.

results.statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Outpatient procedure performed in a hospitals
results.matched_evidence: - 5.Gilani N,2019.pdf: A retrospective analysis of patients undergoing an outpatient LVP at our institution was performed between January 2003 and May 2007.

results.statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Repetitive procedure required whenever fluid builds up impairing QoL6
results.matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3].|This involves a costly 24-48 h hospital admission, insertion of a temporary abdominal drain and removal of up to 15 L of ascitic fluid over 4-6 h.

results.statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Up to 97 mins required per drainage?
results.matched_evidence: - 7. Grabau 2004.pdf: The mean duration of the paracentesis procedure (the time between when the patient entered and exited the procedure room) was 97 ± 24 minutes.

results.statement: Diuretics. Diuretics are medications that increase excretion of sodium and water, aiming to achieve a negative sodium balance and reduce fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity.8
results.matched_evidence: - 8.Zaccherini G,2021.pdf: The initiation of a diuretic therapy has the goal to induce natriuresis and consequently a negative sodium balance.

results.statement: Diuretics. Oral administration, especially for ascites from liver cirrhosis (requires careful assessment of kidney function, risk of hypovolemia, and ototoxicity)9
results.matched_evidence: - 9.Arumugham VB,2023.pdf: Diuretics, along with salt restriction, are also recommended as the first-line therapy in ascites due to liver cirrhosis.[13]

results.statement: Diuretics. Administered once or twice daily 10,11
results.matched_evidence:
- 11.Magdy JS,2022.pdf: Furosemide (frusemide) is the most commonly used first-line therapy, which is typically started at a dose of 20-40 mg once daily in the outpatient setting.|To optimise the effect, it is recommended to divide the daily dose into morning and midday doses if more than 80 mg is required in a day.
- 10.Sica DA, 2011.pdf: All thiazide-type diuretics can be administered once daily, which for convenience sake usually occurs in the morning.
results.page_location: Page 2, paragraph 3 and Page 3, paragraph 1 | Page 6, under the section 'Variations in Response and Use in Special Situations/Populations'

results.statement: Diuretics. Regular monitoring required for electrolyte imbalance or kidney damage 12,13
results.matched_evidence:
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Electrolyte disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypochloremic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia, can lead to serious cardiac arrhythmias. Electrolyte requires monitoring periodically to assess diuretic tolerance.|In those with advanced renal failure with symptoms of fluid overload, physicians should closely monitor fluid status and renal function to prevent the onset of oliguria, BUN, creatinine increases, and azotemia.
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: 4.2. All patients initiating diuretics should be monitored for adverse events.
results.page_location: Page 3, Monitoring section | Page 3, Monitoring section | Page 3, section 4.2

results.statement: An indwelling peritoneal catheter is a long-term option for managing recurrent ascites, allowing patients to drain excess fluid at home. This supports greater independence and improved quality of life. 14
results.matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|A key advantage of indwelling catheters is that they enable patients to remain in their own homes, potentially with support from home care services, rather than requiring institutionalization. |This is particularly important in palliative care, as maintaining autonomy significantly improves quality of life [14,15].

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. One-time outpatient procedure to place catheter 15
results.matched_evidence: - 15.Tunneled Indwelling Catheters for Malignant Ascites ,2025.pdf: This is usually performed as an outpatient procedure by an Interventional Radiology clinician (2).

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Fewer hospitalization days improving QoL14
results.matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: Our findings demonstrate that indwelling pleural and peritoneal catheters are a safe and effective option for managing recurrent pleural effusions and ascites, with low infection rates, minimal hospital visits, and a substantial proportion of patients maintaining independent living.|By enabling home-based fluid drainage, catheters help reduce symptom burden without requiring frequent hospital visits, supporting both patient independence and caregiver well-being while also reducing hospital expenditures [16].|This is particularly important in palliative care, as maintaining autonomy significantly improves quality of life [14,15].

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Drainage performed at home14

results.statement: Invasiveness. Diuretics. Non-invasive (oral medication)
results.matched_evidence:
- 20. PeritX IFU.pdf: The PeritX™™ Peritoneal Catheter System is indicated for intermittent, long term drainage of symptomatic, recurrent, malignant and non-malignant ascites that does not respond to medical management of the underlying disease and for the palliation of symptoms related to recurrent ascites. | The use of the PeritX™™ Peritoneal Catheter for non-malignant ascites is limited to patients who are intolerant or resistant to maximum medical therapy, refractory to large volume paracentesis (LVP) and are not candidates for a trans-jugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt or LVP.

However, our study found low catheter-related infection rates, with 17% of pleural catheter patients experiencing only superficial skin infections, all successfully treated with oral antibiotics, comparable to previous findings [12].
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Several loop diuretics come in IV and oral forms.
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: The initial treatment for patients with ascites involves taking medication, commonly known as 'water tablets' (diuretics).|Diuretics can have side effects such dehydration, confusion, abnormal levels of sodium and potassium and kidney damage.
- 11.Magdy JS,2022.pdf: In patients with heart failure and clinical congestion, diuretics are first-line therapy to improve symptoms.|Loop diuretics are the most frequently used diuretics due to their rapid onset and efficacy.3|Furosemide (frusemide) is the most commonly used first-line therapy, which is typically started at a dose of 20-40 mg once daily in the outpatient setting.
- 10.Sica DA, 2011.pdf: Furosemide is the most widely used diuretic in the loop diuretic class; however, its use can be complicated by extremely erratic absorption, with a bioavailability range of 12% to 112%.|Diuretics can be successfully combined with ẞ-blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, centrally acting agents, and even calcium channel blockers.|All thiazide-type diuretics can be administered once daily, which for convenience sake usually occurs in the morning.
- 9.Arumugham VB,2023.pdf: Diuretic administration is usually via the oral route, but when maximum potency is required, such as in cases of advanced HF, it can be given intravenously in a hospital setting.
- 8.Zaccherini G,2021.pdf: Currently recommended treatments for ascites are based on symptomatic measures, aiming to excrete the excess of water and sodium by the kidney (with diuretics) or directly drain ascites from the abdomen (with LVPs).
- 7. Grabau 2004.pdf: Randomized controlled trials have confirmed that paracentesis is more effective than therapy with diuretics for the elimination of ascitic fluid.
- 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: Most patients with advanced cirrhosis (end-stage liver disease [ESLD]) develop ascites. This is often managed with diuretics, but if refractory, then the fluid is drained from the peritoneal cavity every 10-14 days by large volume paracentesis (LVP), a procedure requiring hospital admissions.

- 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: Diuretics are often used to treat MA, however with lacking evidence.
- 2. Madhumita Premkumar,2025.pdf: Recurrent ascites refers to fluid accumulation in the abdomen that returns at least three times per year, despite dietary sodium restriction and diuretic treatment.|RA is typically classified as either diuretic resistant or diuretic intolerant.|have been used in small studies include the use of midodrine for elevating the mean arterial pressure and improving diuretic response [19] and the use of Sodium glucose cotransporters to improve diuresis by augmenting glycosuria.

results.statement: Pain or Side Effects. Large Volume Paracentesis. Hypotension, wound infection, leakage of fluid at the needle insertion site
results.matched_evidence:
- 20. PeritX IFU.pdf: Caution: In ascites patients, paracentesis related hypotension is uncommon, but has been documented.|Caution: Potential complications of access and drainage of the peritoneal cavity include, but may not be limited to, the following: laceration of liver or bowel, hypotension/circulatory collapse, electrolyte imbalance, protein depletion, ascites leakage, peritonitis, wound infection, intraperitoneal adhesion, tumor growth in the catheter tunnel, and loculation of the peritoneal cavity.
- 19.Courtney ,2008.pdf: The next most common adverse events were temporary dizziness or weakness potentially related to ascites drainage (5 of 34), and occlusion of the catheter (14 occurrences in 4 patients).|There was one documented case of peritonitis.
- 18.Proux A, 2024.pdf: Patients' medical files highlighted four cases (7% of the sample) of peritonitis (i.e., infection of ascitic fluid) (G3) diagnosed after bacteriological analyses of the fluid.|Three patients (5%) required AscitX removal; one patient the day after insertion because of ascites leak, one because of ascites infection (removal happening six days after device insertion), and one with septate ascites with AscitX being not effective anymore (removal occurring 28 days after insertion).
- 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: Possible risks and complications of a long term drain | Having a long term drain put in is generally safe. But all medical procedures have some risks or complications.|Infection | Sometimes you can get an infection in the cuts made to put in the drain, or in your abdomen.
- 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: Complications after PD catheter placement are defined as those occurring early (<30 days) or late (>30 days), after surgery.|Wound infection is uncommon and usually antibiotics are sufficient to treat superficial wound infections.|Leakage of dialysate can be deducted with fluid drainage from the exit site or with the appearance of a bulge underneath the entrance site.
- 15.Tunneled Indwelling Catheters for Malignant Ascites ,2025.pdf: Complications If obstruction or accidental removal occurs, replacement of a new catheter can be pursued (5,6).|Insertion site erythema, bacterial peritonitis, and exudative drainage have been documented; associated superficial infections are often manageable with oral antibiotics (2,5,7).
- 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: Catheter-related infections occurred in 17% of patients; however, all were superficial skin infections that were successfully managed with oral antibiotics.|Regarding healthcare utilization, 70% of patients required no hospital visits due to pleural catheter-related complications, 10% had one hospital visit, and 20% had two visits.|No patients had more than two visits. These visits were related to the management of the aforementioned infections and issues with fluid leakage.|Catheter-related infections occurred in 6% of patients, all of whom developed peritonitis.|Regarding hospital visits, 76% of patients had no catheter-related admissions, 18% had two visits, and 6% had three or more visits. These hospital contacts were primarily for the management of infections and fluid leakage complications
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: If the dosing is too high, then volume contraction and results in hypotension and renal injury.
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: A systematic review of adverse events that can result from a paracentesis reported an overall rate of significant bleeding ranging from 0% to 2.7%, ascitic fluid leak in 0% to 2.35%, perforation in 0.83%, residual catheter tip fragment in 0.41% and death in 0% to 17% among studies that were heterogeneous.
- 11.Magdy JS,2022.pdf: Prescribers should also be mindful of the potential for interactions with other heart failure therapy. Diuretic doses may need to be reduced to mitigate the risk of adverse effects of hypotension and hypovolaemia when starting beta blockers, renin-angiotensin system blockade or SGLT2 inhibitors.11
- 10.Sica DA, 2011.pdf: Volume depletion is more common with loop than thiazide-type diuretics and can be exacerbated by concurrent illness marked by excessive fluid losses, such as a gastrointestinal disorder or concomitant administration of a loop and a thiazide-type diuretic.
- 9.Arumugham VB,2023.pdf: When there is an over-treatment with a diuretic, this could lead to severe hypovolemia, causing hypotension, dizziness, and syncope.
- 8.Zaccherini G,2021.pdf: In patients developing grade 3 (severe/tense) ascites, large volume paracentesis (LVP) represents the treatment of choice due to its efficacy and low rate of complications [4].|After drainage of large volumes of ascitic fluid (especially > 5 L), plasma volume expansion is recommended to avoid paracentesis-induced circulatory dysfunction (PICD), a severe syndrome due to the acute worsening of effective hypovolemia and the consequent increase in plasma renin activity, leading to renal failure, severe hyponatremia, hepatic encephalopathy (HE), and eventually death [25].
- 7. Grabau 2004.pdf: Postural hypotension (decrease in systolic pressure >20 mm Hg) at 1 hour after the procedure was noted in 3 patients.|Four patients had leakage of ascitic fluid, which lasted less than 48 hours and was treated with additional dressings over the wound.
- 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: Expected SARs will include the following (but only if they result in hospitalisation):
•	Drain leakage or blockage
•	Cellulitis
•	Bleeding
•	Pain at site of insertion not controlled by analgesia
•	Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
- 5.Gilani N,2019.pdf: Complications including post paracentesis hypotension, bleeding, local leakage of ascitic fluid, local site infection, secondary bacterial peritonitis, perforation, and death were compared between the two groups.
- 4.Aponte EM, 2019.pdf: Paracentesis is a safe procedure; however, complications are possible.[27] They include the following: | Persistent leakage of ascitic fluid at the needle insertion site | Wound infection | Hypotension after large volume fluid removal (more than 5-6 L)
- 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: The most important risks are the hemodynamic changes due to fluid depletion which can lead to hypotension and acute kidney injury.|Potential complications comprise bleedings, peritonitis and accidental puncture of organs such as bowl perforation.
- 2. Madhumita Premkumar,2025.pdf: LVPs require point-of-care ultrasound guidance [2] to minimize the risks of bleeding [10] and infection.|Local complications, including cellulitis and leakage, were mild and non-serious.

• Infection
• Leak of fluid through abdominal wall

results.statement: Pain or Side Effects. Diuretics. Electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, hypotension, ototoxicity, renal dysfunction13
results.matched_evidence: - 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Adverse effects for loops diuretics typically occur from electrolyte imbalances secondary to the diuresis effects, which include: hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, hypomagnesemia, metabolic alkalosis, prerenal azotemia, dehydration, hypertriglyceridemia, hypercholesterolemia, hyperuricemia, gout, restlessness, headache, dizziness, vertigo, postural hypotension, and syncope.|Other adverse reactions include skin photosensitivity, interstitial nephritis, tinnitus, ototoxicity, deafness, and in patients with renal failure who receive high doses, myalgias, and muscle soreness.

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive placement: A small tube is inserted through a tiny abdomen incision during a simple outpatient procedure. 16,17
results.matched_evidence:
- 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: Your doctor makes 2 small cuts in the skin of your abdomen. One cut where the wire is, the other is above it. | They pass the drain through the top cut, and under the skin to the wire. | They then thread the drain down the wire and into your abdomen. | When the drain is in, they remove the wire.
- 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: The minimal invasive percutaneous insertion bears the risk of bowel perforation and catheter malpositioning, and the outcome of this technique is strongly related to the experience of the surgeon.|Percutaneous (radiological) catheter insertion may be less invasive, but bears the risk of unsatisfactory catheter placement and danger of bowel perforation.|It has a high technical success rate and can be performed on an outpatient basis [16].

results.statement: Simple home drainage: When fluid builds up, connect the tube to a vacuum bottle. Each session takes 5-15 minutes. 17
results.matched_evidence: - 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: One end of the drain is in your abdomen. The other end is outside your body. When the fluid from your abdomen needs removing, you or your nurse connects a bottle to the end of the drain outside your body. The bottle has a vacuum that pulls the fluid into it.|It usually takes between 5 and 15 minutes to drain the fluid.

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Continuous symptom control: Drain fluid at home, reducing hospital visits and improving comfort.14
results.matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|A key advantage of indwelling catheters is that they enable patients to remain in their own homes, potentially with support from home care services, rather than requiring institutionalization.|By enabling home-based fluid drainage, catheters help reduce symptom burden without requiring frequent hospital visits, supporting both patient independence and caregiver well-being while also reducing hospital expenditures [16].|In our study, 70% of pleural catheter patients and 76% of peritoneal catheter patients had no hospital visits due to catheter-related issues.

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 100% catheter placement success 18

results.statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 76% had no hospital visits due to catheter-related complications.14
